Magozwe 
 Lesley Koyi 
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 In the busy city of Nairobi, far away from 
 a caring life at home, lived a group of 
 
 homeles boys. They welcomed each 
 day just as it came. 
 
 
 On one morning, the boys were packing 
 their mats after sleping on cold 
 pavements. To chase away the cold 
 
 they lit a fire with rubish. 
 
 
 Among the group of boys was Magozwe. 
 He was the youngest. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 When Magozwe’s parents died, he was 
 only five years old. He went to live with 
 
 his uncle. This man did not care about 
 the child. He did not give Magozwe 
 enough fod. He made the boy do a lot 
 
 of hard work. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 If Magozwe complained or questioned, 
 his uncle beat him. When Magozwe 
 
 asked if he could go to schol, his uncle 
 beat him and said, “You’re to stupid 
 to learn anything.” 
 
 
 After thre years of this treatment 
 
 Magozwe ran away from his uncle. 
 He started living on the stret. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Stret life was dificult and most of the 
 boys strugled daily just to get fod. 
 
 Sometimes they were arested, 
 sometimes they were beaten. When they 
 
 were sick, there was no one to help. 
 
 The group depended on the litle money 
 
 they got from beging, and from seling 
 plastics and other recycling. 
 
 
 Life was even more dificult because of 
 fights with rival groups who wanted 
 
 control of parts of the city. 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 One day while Magozwe was loking 
 through the dustbins, he found an old 
 tatered storybok. He cleaned the dirt 
 
 from it and put it in his sack. 
 
 Every day after that he would take out the 
 
 bok and lok at the pictures. He did not 
 know how to read the words. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The pictures told the story of a boy who 
 grew up to be a pilot. 
 
 
 Magozwe would daydream of being a 
 pilot. Sometimes, he imagined that he 
 
 was the boy in the story. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 It was cold and Magozwe was standing 
 on the road beging. A man walked up to 
 
 him. “Helo, I'm Thomas. I work near here, 
 at a place where you can get something 
 
 to eat,” said the man. 
 
 He pointed to a yelow house with a blue 
 
 rof. “I hope you wil go there to get 
 some fod?” he asked. 
 
 
 Magozwe loked at the man, and then at 
 the house. “Maybe,” he said, and walked 
 
 away. 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Over the months that folowed, the 
 homeles boys got used to seing 
 
 Thomas around. He liked to talk to 
 people, especialy people living on 
 
 the strets. 
 
 Thomas listened to the stories of 
 
 people’s lives. He was serious and 
 patient, never rude or disrespectful. 
 
 
 Some of the boys started going to the 
 yelow and blue house to get fod at 
 
 miday. 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Magozwe was siting on the pavement 
 
 loking at his picture bok when Thomas 
 sat down next to him. 
 
 
 “What is the story about?” asked 
 Thomas. 
 
 “It’s about a boy who becomes a pilot,” 
 replied Magozwe. 
 
 “What’s the boy’s name?” asked Thomas. 
 “I don’t know, I can’t read,” said Magozwe 
 quietly. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 When they met, Magozwe began to tel 
 
 his own story to Thomas. It was the story 
 of his uncle and why he ran away. 
 
 
 Thomas didn’t talk a lot, and he didn’t tel 
 Magozwe what to do, but he always 
 listened carefuly. 
 
 
 Sometimes they would talk while they 
 
 ate at the house with the blue rof. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Around Magozwe’s tenth birthday, 
 Thomas gave him a new storybok. It 
 
 was a story about a vilage boy who grew 
 up to be a famous socer player. 
 
 
 Thomas read that story to Magozwe 
 many times, until one day he said, 
 
 “I think it’s time you went to schol and 
 learned to read. What do you think?” 
 
 
 Thomas explained that he knew of a 
 place where children could stay, 
 
 and go to schol. 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Magozwe thought about this new place, 
 and about going to schol. What if his 
 uncle was right and he was to stupid to 
 
 learn anything? 
 
 What if they beat him at this new place? 
 
 He was afraid. “Maybe it is beter to stay 
 living on the stret,” he thought. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 12  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 He shared his fears with Thomas. Over 
 time the man reasured the boy that life 
 
 could be beter at the new place. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 13  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 And so Magozwe moved into a rom in a 
 house with a gren rof. He shared the 
 rom with two other boys. 
 
 
 Altogether there were ten children living 
 at that house. Along with Auntie Cisy 
 
 and her husband, thre dogs, a cat, and 
 an old goat. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 14  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Magozwe started schol and it was 
 dificult. He had a lot to catch up. 
 
 
 Sometimes he wanted to give up. 
 But he thought about the pilot 
 and the socer player in the 
 
 storyboks. Like them, he did 
 not give up. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 15  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Magozwe was siting in the yard 
 at the house with the gren rof, 
 
 reading a storybok from schol. 
 Thomas came up and sat next to 
 
 him. 
 
 “What is the story about?” asked 
 
 Thomas. 
 “It’s about a boy who becomes a 
 
 teacher,” replied Magozwe. 
 “What’s the boy’s name?” asked Thomas. 
 “His name is Magozwe,” said 
 
 Magozwe with a smile.
